IV means uncertainty. Uncertainty overprices options. Overpriced options means profit option writers can take. If you want to work with small capital amounts (i.e. <$50,000) you need to be in high IV and you need to be working with things that are efficient at using capital as collateral. 30 delta even 30 DTE on something as low IV as SPY is going to be, what, a quarter in premium? Waiting a month to make $25 while tying up hundreds in collateral?

Look for edge. Look for POP. Look for short expiries. Let the positions run but get out of the position once you've pulled a good proportion of the profit. Send it into another opportunity that's waiting instead of spending a week eking out those few extra cents of theta. You've got to keep your average edge high, your positions numerous and varied, and money moving through the system from profit to opportunity. Make income from large numbers of small positions that are both profitable and likely to pan out. Where will you find them? High IV.

Hey. Didn‚Äôt read all the comments. I sold credit spreads for 2 years as my full time job (by ‚Äúfull time‚Äù I mean I worked 15 minutes a day). Everything went really well. I placed I don‚Äôt know how many trades, thousands upon thousands. I sold spreads 30-45 DTE delta 12 on short put, $500 spread (or difference of $5 between long and short e.g. 150/145 strikes). 

I live in a low cost-of-living country, and was making between $2000 and $10000 a month, so I had way more money than I needed. Moreover, I had a success rate of over 99.5%, so you can guess how big of an ego I had.

In October of 2018 I decided to take my boyfriend on a trip to Paris and Beirut. I put us in expensive hotels and took us to the fanciest restaurants. 

I was convinced I had found what I was going to do for the rest of my life.

During the trip my positions started going against me. I stupidly didn‚Äôt bring my computer with me, and at that time it was difficult to close spreads on the Interactive Brokers mobile app, plus the internet was shoddy in Beirut and I just figured it would turn around like it always did and I‚Äôd fix it when I got back. I sold more spreads into the downturn, thinking there was no way it could get worse. 

On the last day of the trip we were in the airport in Paris. It was a Saturday, and I opened my account out of boredom to see that my $170,000 account was now worth $100,000. 

Over the next week I tried desperately to repair my positions but it was nearly impossible. Every day I was waking up to margin calls or $1 million or $2 million, getting assigned left and right. I was trading ETFs like SPY, QQQ, and IWM, so not even anything that risky.

By the end of the week, my portfolio was worth $30,000; and I was on the verge of a heart attack. I lost $140,000 in six days. I closed it and walked away.

I wound up having to go back to work. 

Anyways, I am writing this to you to tell you that assignment can happen at any time on American-style options. You have to be very careful with put spreads because you can easily get assigned on the short put; and if your long put has expired by the time you realize you‚Äôve been assigned, you‚Äôre up Shit Creek.

Morals of the story - holding spreads to expiry when the short put is near the money is a bad idea; and if you go on vacation or go somewhere without good internet, it‚Äôs better to close everything before you go, or at least the positions that will expire while you‚Äôre away or are close to the money. 

Hope you are able to work it out on Monday morning!

A bunch of them on the call side, if they hit Wednesday closing price are going to be 40 baggers, like BAC.

BAC is at $24.8, $25.5C expiring today costs $0.04, and on Wednesday close it's $26.51.

The script also filters our poor liquidity options to ensure it's relatively reasonable to enter and exit them.

To elaborate on the columns,

**Tendies Index** - How many times the option will multibag if price target is hit at expiry, assuming you can enter midpoint between bid/ask

**NTR** - A modified ATR value using past 10 days true range, but discard the highest and 4 lowest, then averaging the remaining 5.

**Price Target** - Current price + NTR = Price target for calls, Current price - NTR = price target for puts.

The way to use this is, if you think the probability of hitting price target is greater than 1/Tendiex Index, then it's a trade with expected positive value. I believe option mispricing do occur at a higher rate in extreme cases like far OTM 0 DTE, or Thursday before close. Still, this is just a good filter, you'll still need to pick your plays.

Okay, so long story short, why you get destroyed by ERs in general is IV crush, which is where implied volatility doubles before ER and halves after ER. Basically if you bought a call or put, and the stock doesn't move hugely in your chosen direction, the value of that option instantly drops by -40%~, regardless of delta changes. This is why its recommended to sell before all ERs due to the gambling nature of price movement. Additionally, monthly expirations are usually set within 4~ days of most ERs, which means your monthlies turn into weeklies if you hold; so when you're wrong about direction, you lose huge on both IV crush and theta loss.

How I make plays through ERs and not lose my ass are 2 ways:

1) Buy much longer DTE options. For example when I'm playing ERs this month for Aug stocks, I'm buying Sept calls and LEAPs. When I'm wrong I can still baghold and get my money back. It's true I don't get huge paydays from gambling, I also don't obliterate my account Exodia Yu-Gi-Oh style.

2) Buy your options far out from ERs in general on red days. I make a list a month ahead of time for all ERs and update it weekly. I'm looking to buy on Thursday and Fridays 30+ DTE calls on things I like. So when IV jumps the week of ERs, you get IV love, not crush, which instantly gives you a 20%+ boost in options value instead of loss.

4. Roll the long put down for a huge credit. This will widen your spread, effectively increasing your risk, but also netting you some nice premium, taking advantage of an increase in IV. This also serves to lower your break even. This is essentially a ‚Äúdoubling down‚Äù play.

ITM debit spreads or OTM credit spreads both allow wiggle room/downside protection/upside protection (depending on your exact entry) while still being able to make money by expiration. High win rates are easily achievable when you enter a position that has some protection built in. Mind you, you're talking positions that may be (for example) risking $80 to win $20 on a $1 wide spread, but has 10+% protection for moves against you. The numbers will vary depending on DTE, IV, and the greeks of course.

Now I do agree that buying spreads on OTM long calls or puts is pretty stupid, as you do need a move in your favor and they'll print like crazy when they do, but that's not what a proper spread entry is.

FOR EXAMPLE, using $JPM's closing figures as of 10/6/2020 (2 minutes ago), the stock is currently trading at $98.02; you can buy a $95C and sell a $96C both expiring this Friday for around $.85. If $JPM finishes Friday above $96, both of your calls are exercised and you make $15. This play has $2 of downside protection built in and is still a winner. This is how high winrates are not only possible, but actually expected on proper spreads (the $JPM play is really not a good entry, I'm just spitting out an example of how they can make money while moving against you).

Let's say the underlying is trading at 100, and the 45 DTE call at 100 is trading at a price of 5. This value of 5 is the amount the market judges is fair to compensate the seller for the risk of the stock being up in 45 days. Such a value is called **extrinsic value**.

Now take the 45 DTE Call at 90, trading at a price of 14. If you buy it, you can exercise it at once, for 10 (100 - 90) per underlying unit. 10 is called the **intrinsic value**. You can also see it as the value of the contract if the underlying does not move until expiration. What's left (4) represents the actual compensation to the seller for the risk of the stock being over 90 in 45 days, that is to say the extrinsic value. The extrinsic value decreases over time when the underlying does not move, which is known as **theta decay**.

As you can see, although the raw price itself if higher for the ITM option, you're actually paying less risk premium to the seller. That is because you yourself are taking the risk of seeing your instrinsic value disappear. You will lose less money through the passage of time (theta decay), but your exposure to the underlying itself (delta) is greater since you will lose more if the underlying decreases.

ATM or OTM options are 100% extrinsic value. 

A call at 0 would be 100% intrinsic value.
